title: Ole Gunnar Solskjaer hails Martin Atkinson for role in Man Utd goal vs Liverpool
text:

Ole Gunnar Solskjaer has praised referee Martin Atkinson for his role in Man Utd's goal against Liverpool on Sunday.

The United boss saw his side overcome their recent troubles to earn a point at home to the league leaders.

Solskjaer's side took the lead in the first half when Marcus Rashford converted Daniel James' cross after a quick counter attack started by Scott McTominay.

The goal came about in controversial fashion, with Liverpool complaining of a foul on Divock Origi in the build-up, but Solskjaer was happy with the referees contribution.

Speaking of the goal, Solskjaer said: "Scotty's thought to go forward straight away. Marcus' movement is fantastic and a great cross from James.

(Image: AFP via Getty Images)

"What pleased me the most? The referees' position because he is nowhere near it."

Despite being some distance from Rashford when he put the all in the net, Atkinson was right on top of the flashpoint involving Origi.

United defender Victor Lindelof appeared to make contact with Origi, who was sent tumbling to the turf.

But Atkinson allowed play to continue, with United scoring immediately on the break, before he consulted VAR who deemed it not to be a clear and obvious error, and the goal stood.

(Image: AFP via Getty Images)

Reds boss Jurgen Klopp was visibly irate at the decision, and slammed the call after the match.

"They were better than us and defended well, but in the end they scored a goal that shows all the problems with VAR," Klopp fumed.

"Mr Atkinson let the game run on because that is the protocol of VAR, and VAR shows there was contact and it was a foul."

However Solskjaer was keen to point to the work of his side in shackling Klopp's side, who only drew level through a late goal from substitute Adam Lallana.

(Image: Offside via Getty Images)

"The fans were unbelievable and the boys started it," Solskjaer said. "We started on the front foot, pressed them and made them uncomfortable.

"It was part of the plan to have energy up front to unsettle them.

"We had a little plan and our fingers crossed that we could everyone back fit. We have lots of centre backs who I trust one vs one. I knew Liverpool could cause problems but we took that risk.

(Image: Manchester United via Getty Imag)

"It is down to Ashley [Young] and Aaron [Wan-Bissaka], who were brave to push onto the full-backs. That was a risk and it worked."

In spite of their efforts, the Red Devils remain in the bottom half of the table in 13th, and Solskjaer admitted his team needed to start turning performances into points.

"We have had some good performances but we need results," he added. "It is good to see the boys are disappointed. We have to kick on and start winning games."
description: The match official allowed the game to play on despite a flashpoint involving Divock Origi which allowed United to score
